source: Perplexity AI-generated content for GitHub & Open Source Etiquette, beginner to expert

level_1: GitHub is a platform for sharing and collaborating on code projects using version control.
You can create repositories to store your code and track changes over time.
Open source means anyone can view, use, and contribute to a project.
Good etiquette helps everyone work together smoothly.
You’ll learn to use branches, commits, and pull requests to contribute safely.
level_2: Git is the tool that tracks changes; GitHub is where you share your work online.
You’ll practice making pull requests, reviewing code, and resolving conflicts.
Following contribution guidelines and writing clear commit messages is important.
Respectful communication and prompt responses build a healthy community.
Understanding licenses and permissions is part of open source participation.
level_3: Advanced users help review others' code and maintain project documentation.
They manage issues, triage bugs, and guide new contributors.
Maintainers enforce code standards and resolve disputes.
They automate workflows with GitHub Actions and protect main branches.
They encourage diversity and inclusion in open source communities.
level_4: Experts lead large open source projects and set community standards.
They mentor contributors, organize events, and manage project governance.
They handle security disclosures and ensure compliance with licenses.
They create templates for issues, PRs, and codes of conduct.
They advocate for open source best practices at conferences and in publications.
